headline: 11+ years and still a great place to work
pros: I really appreciate the people, culture, and balance afforded by Google.
cons: Advancing the career ladder is very challenging. Each level is like another PhD in some ways.

headline: Moving at the speed of light, burn out is inevitable
pros:
1) Food, food, food.  15+ cafes on main campus (MTV) alone.  Mini-kitchens, snacks, drinks, free breakfast/lunch/dinner, all day, errr'day.

2) Benefits/perks.  Free 24:7 gym access (on MTV campus).  Free (self service) laundry (washer/dryer) available.  Bowling alley.  Volley ball pit.  Custom-built and exclusive employee use only outdoor sport park (MTV).  Free health/fitness assessments.  Dog-friendly.  Etc. etc. etc.

3) Compensation.  In ~2010 or 2011, Google updated its compensation packages so that they were more competitive.  

4) For the size of the organization (30K+), it has remained relatively innovative, nimble, and fast-paced and open with communication but, that is definitely changing (for the worse).

5) With so many departments, focus areas, and products, *in theory*, you should have plenty of opportunity to grow your career (horizontally or vertically).  In practice, not true.  

6)  You get to work with some of the brightest, most innovative and hard-working/diligent minds in the industry.  There's a "con" to that, too (see below).
cons:
1) Work/life balance.  What balance?  All those perks and benefits are an illusion.  They keep you at work and they help you to be more productive.  I've never met anybody at Google who actually time off on weekends or on vacations.  You may not hear management say, "You have to work on weekends/vacations" but, they set the culture by doing so - and it inevitably trickles down.  I don't know if Google inadvertently hires the work-a-holics or if they create work-a-holics in us.  Regardless, I have seen way too many of the following: marriages fall apart, colleagues choosing work and projects over family, colleagues getting physically sick and ill because of stress, colleagues crying while at work because of the stress, colleagues shooting out emails at midnight, 1am, 2am, 3am.  It is absolutely ridiculous and something needs to change.

2) Poor management.  I think the issue is that, a majority of people love Google because they get to work on interesting technical problems - and these are the people that see little value in learning how to develop emotional intelligence.  Perhaps they enjoy technical problems because people are too "difficult."  People are promoted into management positions - not because they actually know how to lead/manage, but because they happen to be smart or because there is no other path to grow into.  So there is a layer of intelligent individuals who are horrible managers and leaders.  Yet, there is no value system to actually do anything about that because "emotional intelligence" or "adaptive leadership" are not taken seriously.

3) Jerks.  Sure, there are a lot of brilliant people - but, sadly, there are also a lot of jerks (and, many times, they are one and the same).  Years ago, that wasn't the case.  I don't know if the pool of candidates is getting smaller, or maybe all the folks with great personalities cashed out and left, or maybe people are getting burned out and it's wearing on their personality and patience.  I've heard stories of managers straight-up cussing out their employees and intimidating/scaring their employees into compliance.

4) It's a giant company now and, inevitably, it has become slower moving and is now layered with process and bureaucracy.  So many political battles, empire building, territory grabbing.  Google says, "Don't be evil."  But, that practice doesn't seem to be put into place when it comes to internal practices.  :(

headline: Great balance between big-company security and fun, fast-moving projects
pros:
* If you're a software engineer, you're among the kings of the hill at Google. It's an engineer-driven company without a doubt (that *is* changing, but it's still very engineer-focused).
* The perks are amazing. Yes, free breakfast, lunch, an dinner every weekday. Aaaaaamazing holiday parties (at Waldorf Astoria, NY Public Library, MoMA, etc.); overnight ski trips to Vermont; overnight nature trips to the Poconos in the summer; summer picnics at Chelsea piers; and on and on and on. I don't see this going away unless the company starts hurting financially.
* Speaking of which, the company is doing quite well, which reflects in bonuses and equity grants.
* There a huge diversity of work ranging from defending independent journalism worldwide (Google Project Shield) to crisis response during disasters (see Maps during Hurricane Sandy or Tsunamis), to the best machine learning experts and projects in the world, to more mundane revenue-driving projects in advertising, there's really something for everybody.
* It's easy to move around within the company as long as you're in good standing (the vast majority of engineers are).
* The company is amazingly open: every week Larry Page and Sergey Brin host what's called TGIF where food, beer, wine, etc. is served, a new project is presented, and afterward there's an open forum to ask the executives anything you want. It's truly fair game to ask anything, no matter how controversial, and frequently the executives will be responsive.
* No, nobody cares if you use an iPhone, Facebook, shop with Amazon, stream using Spotify, or refuse to use Google+. The company is amazingly open and flexible.

Neither pro nor con, but general information on work-life balance, promotions, and advancement.
* Work life balance can be what you want it to be on most teams. (Some teams are in more competitive sectors and require more crazy hours all the time - but very few of them). If you do what's expected, you'll be fine at least for a handful of years. Working a roughly 40 hour work week is possible, and many people do it. There are also people who are hyper-motived and work like crazy just because they love it, or because they're competitive, or they want to get a promotion. If you work 40 hour weeks without putting in anything extra, you'll fall behind them as they advance and you stand still - and maybe that doesn't matter, so it works out for everybody. But at least know where you would realistically stand.
* If you excel and work your butt off, you'll be compensated and promoted. If you let yourself be a code monkey, and just sit coding with your head down all day, you'll be fine but won't advance. A big complaint from some Googlers is about not being able to advance "even at Google" with pure coding. Sure, if you're the uber genius who created MapReduce and Bigtable, you're going to advance like a rocket without having to do anything but coding; but if you're like most engineers at Google -- smarter than average, but just average compared to other Googlers -- you're just a good coder and not revolutionary. Code monkeys are important to actually get stuff done, and to be sure you absolutely need to be a good coder as a software engineer (it's the minimum requirement), but code monkeys won't advance because they're not leaders and they're easy to replace. To get promoted you need to lead and do more than just code. There are plenty of ways to lead other than being an official tech lead, so this isn't actually _that_ hard, so the real point is just that you can't just sit there coding what other people tell you to code all day and expect to advance.
cons:
* It *is* becoming larger, and with it comes growing pains: bureaucracy, slow to respond to market threats, bloated teams, cross-divisional tension (though nothing remotely approaching that of Microsoft's internal tension).
* The quality of the engineers is possibly dropping, but possibly not. It's hard to get real metrics, because as the absolute number of people grows, naturally the number of bad apples grows; as a percentage it's supposedly the same as it ever was, but with larger numbers of poorer quality engineers it just _feels_ like things might be changing for the worse.
* Also with growth means more internal-confidential data leaks (again, because of the raw numbers of people) -- product announcements being ruined, etc. That means the company has to be tighter-lipped internally to avoid leaks, which makes things less open. It's still an amazingly open place, but less so than it was even a couple years ago. The good thing is they recognize it and actively look to improve things because they know how important it is to keep the good culture.

headline: The best place I've worked and also the most demanding.
pros:
You can't find a more well-regarded company that actually deserves the hype it gets.

You'll work on cutting edge projects / solve important issues that impact your community and the world

You'll meet interesting people who are your colleagues, managers, and senior management.

You'll open the paper and see your company in the news almost every day, and read about projects you're working on, which is a cool thing

You'll see Larry and Sergey at TGIF and you'll admire how they lead the company. They are brilliant, goofy, low key but intense, and likeable. 

There are 22 cafes (more or less), the food is excellent, and it's free.

Your pay will typically be competitive, though it needs to be tweaked up a bit since the economy has improved.

Google cares about how it treats its employees.

The campus is like an academic campus in many ways.

There are tons of activities on campus, like authors speaking about their books, films after work, and gyms where you can work out - but you'll need to make sure to carve out time to do these things.

You'll get plenty of external validation from people who suddenly think you're smart and rich because you work there, even if you're not rich and you're as smart when you didn't work at Google.

If and when you leave, you'll never regret having that company on your resume. It opens doors. 

The company is flexible - if you're lucky, you won't have a micromanager boss and you can be somewhat flexible in how you work - but don't get me wrong - you'll work a LOT. But you don't have to do all of it chained to your desk.
cons:
I live in SF so the commute can take between 1.5 hours to 1.75 hours each way on the shuttle - sometimes 2 hours each way on a busy day or rainy day. That means being on the bus for 3-4 hours PER DAY. It's a wired bus though which means you can work on the way to Mountain View. But it can feel brutal.

Your first year or two are really important in terms of your career at Google and they affect how you're viewed, and your ability to be promoted. You should always ask to work on high profile projects. If you don't get them, don't expect to get high ratings or get promoted. Always volunteer for cross functional group work for maximum exposure, and then work hard at those things.

You'll likely work on something that no one will explain to you and it will take you at least a year to be comfortable doing what you're working on, even if you're super quick at learning.  No one has time to train you or teach you what you're doing - which is kind of hard.

After two or three years, people you started out with at Google start to get promoted. If you're not one of them, you'll wonder why and how it happened, and that process is somewhat political and not always clear. 

It's a big company now. And super political. So don't be naive. Expect some people to be catty, some people to be territorial, and be prepared to be mentally tough. Don't let people see your vulnerableness. It's a Darwinistic culture with a huge dose of 30-something idealism on top which can fool you into thinking that people are easygoing - they're not. They're driven. If you're not driven, you're not going to fit in.

When you start at Google, it seems like peer reviews are super important - they are, but they are the sprinkles on the fro yo. The important thing is that your direct manager knows your work, likes your work and likes you, and then you can get promoted. If your boss doesn't like you, all the positive peer reviews in the world won't help you.  Make sure you know what your boss wants, and give it to them. You will have weekly one on ones, and make sure you are addressing your performance at each one, asking if they have questions, how you can improve, can you work on cross functional projects, etc.

It's really hard to find work life balance at Google. The workload is huge.   I hardly have time to work out. The commute is brutal. My family sometimes needs more from me and I can't give it. I'm still trying to find the balance. I think I need more down time than most people so I have a hard time being structured every day to fit all the things I want into my day, so a lot of things slip, like working out.

headline: Good company (If you’re a fresh grad or want a stable life)
pros: Hands down one of the best tech companies in the world. For a company this size, it’s very progressive and forward thinking. If you’re a fresh grad you’ll learn how to work within a system and learn from some of the best in the business. If you are a very capable person and are tired of grinding at a smaller company, Google is also a great place to cruise. You’ll get decently challenging projects without the stress of having to produce right away. If you’re looking for a big company with good pay, stability and flexibility. Look no further.
cons: If you’re looking for a more challenging job or want to be able to see your impact faster, this is not the place to be. If you prefer to grow into your role instead of being groomed for a role then you’ll have to look elsewhere. As progressive and flat as a big company can be, Google at the end of the day IS still A BIG COMPANY, you will inevitably feel like a cog in a giant machine just like being in any other big companies.

headline: Google Recruiting
author_position: Senior Technical Recruiter Or Recruiting Manager
pros: Google has incredible resources for learning high-tech and managing teams. There is outstanding onboarding, process documentation, and shadowing for new joiners. Google also has a strong work-life balance, anchoring meetings to midday to respect national timezones. The community of individuals is top-notch- amazingly smart, driven, and courteous colleagues.
cons: Given the scale of the operation, it's very hard to create change. The best opportunities and problems are often "gifted" down from managers to select individuals who are on fast promotion trajectories. Challenges are often framed so positively, it can feel impossible to ask the "real question," criticize efforts, or swim upstream. I saw individuals sent a strong message with their ratings for challenging the status quo. At times, this can feel toxic and insurmountable. The key here is aligning to strong managers who are transparent and supportive so you can get tapped for meaningful work, find a safe space for challenging assumptions, and get buy-in for your ideas.

headline: Good place to start your career, but don't lose sight of what you truly want
pros:
- Superb, industry leading infrastructure.
- Good internal openness, at least used to have.
- Watch people working on amazing, innovative projects in action.
cons:
- Management either seems unaccountable for their results, e.g. managers doing terrible things to products get promoted; or they seem too focused on quick result, harming Google's reputation and overall product in the process.
- If you lose sight of what you really want to do in life, it is easy to spend a few years at Google being really comfortable, and then realize you are further away from your goals.

headline: Bad impression at the front door
pros:
- smiling recruiters.
- interesting tasks on the interviews.
cons:
I do not know how good Google is inside, however the interview process and HR is a face of the company. In my situation this face did not look good.
The hiring process is extremely long. However, I can admit, this time the sessions were much more interesting than all years before.

Since my recruiter said I passed the interview process and now I am on the team matching phase I thought it can take month or so. I was wrong. I took 3.5 months and based on my research this is not a max. Some people should wait months up to the year on this stage. However, this is not the end of the story. My recruiter were disappearing for a weeks and I had to ask her about
any updates. As a result, my emails sunk on the bottom of Atlantic Ocean. She replied in 3 weeks saying she had technical problems. Maybe, I do not know. Everything can happen in our complicated life. 
 Finally I got several teams to speak with. Awesome! It took 2 weeks to finalize the process and pick a nice team. During this process with Google I had several parallel processes with other companies. On the final stages I rejected all offers I had in my hand wishing to work at Google and learn tons of new staff and do something extraordinary. Why not, if I was already presented to the hiring committee and recruiter updated “We are finalizing your final offer”. It was a relaxing time. 
 In 1.5 weeks I got a call from Google and heard “A review team (hiring committee) decided to reject you. We made several errors. We apologize and want to keep in touch. You can try again in one year”. Nice outcome!

Advice to people who want to join Google:
- Keep in mind the process is extremely long at Google! For me it took 7 months.
- Never ever reject other offers from other interesting companies if you are in the process with Google. However, it is hard to extend such offers, while you are waiting Google. 
- I would estimate the approximate total compensation you can get (or may not) from Google, all pros and cons of the area of work and make a decision about offers in your hand.

headline: Still awesome
pros: I've been here for five years now, and this place is still the best engineering environment that I have been a part of in my 15-year career. Code quality and automated testing is taken seriously. Code reviews are often rigorous and provide an amazing learning opportunity. You can have language experts review your code!
cons:
As stated elsewhere, there is enormous complexity. Google is a very large company, and unfortunately nothing is simple. Getting something done, something that doesn't seem especially difficult, can take longer than it should. 

Asynchronous workflows are the bane of my existence. You are always managing multiple work-streams: one is blocked on review, another is blocked on release, etc. It's annoying that I can't just "do things" as easily. But when the stuff is finally done it feels pretty great.

headline: A great place to be even if it's grown in size and complexity
pros: Amazing benefits, general culture of friendliness / kindness / collaboration. Not all orgs are like this, but the ones I've been in are generally filled with people that want to do the right thing for their teams and their people, which makes employees feel very supported and safe.
cons: Size - Google is so complex and huge now it's harder to get anything done efficiently if you're in a larger part of the organization. Internal mobility outside of your org and direct area of expertise can feel daunting.

headline: Your experience really depends on the team
pros:
- Perks (free food, discounts on goods, massage points, gym, laundry, tons of stuff I'm forgetting)
- Health benefits. I'm on the PPO, which allows OON care. There's also more or less unlimited sick days and disability leave
- Decent accommodations for my disability. Can't speak too well to other people's disability accommodations, but it does look like they're trying
- All my coworkers respect my pronouns (they/them)
- Work/life balance is what you make of it. You have flexible hours and can come in more or less whenever you want. Still, most people work 50-60 hours. It's possible to do 40, but don't expect to get promoted. Nominally, work/life balance is encouraged, but secretly, it really isn't.
cons: If you're on a big team, the bureaucracy is enormous. Good luck getting anything done when you have a billion approval processes to go through. Also the organization structure is incredibly unstable. You will have a new manager every 1-3 years even if you stay on the same team just from reorgs.

headline: A large company with increasing hierarchy, but still amazing benefits.
pros:
Work culture (ie values, priorities, performance reviews, remote work) is largely determined at the organization / Director level now. People in different organizations can have vastly different experiences, and it's valuable to get to know your future coworkers to have a better understanding of the work environment, expectations, and teams you'd be collaborating closely with.

Teams aim to be strategic, highly efficient, and action-oriented.

There are tons of different active interest groups to participate in and meet people across the company. Great office spaces, amazing food, and exposure to lots of ideas.
cons: Roles can be very specialized, and mobility between job ladders / roles is more difficult than you may think (ie switching from UX Design to Product Manager). You would need to gain relevant experience in your current role with a 120% project, or have the relevant previous experience to interview as if you were an external candidate.

headline: 90% a utopia...10% dystopia
pros:
+ managers seem to work hard to find the right level of comfort / challenge
+ definitely some interesting perspectives
+ have the tools to do your job
+ lots of autonomy
cons:
- PMs act like little CEOs. They take a lot of ownership of their project and can make others feel like they're working in an agency
- process, process, process
- the loud researchers are highly opinionated
- easy to trick yourself into working longer/harder
- VERY performance oriented, which works well because most people seem like they enjoyed getting straight As their entire lives (this kind of sucks if you like, uh, taking it easy and not being stressed)
- people may have very different backgrounds, but they have similar ways of thinking about problems, which I'm not sure ultimately helps the people using the products.

headline: Good place to work. Beware of drinking the kool-aid though!
pros:
Amazing colleagues
Great learning
You can tell your friends you work there & they'll be in awe
Good internal mobility - with caveats
cons:
Compensation & levelling are negotiated at hire. If you get down-levelled at hire then there is no easy way out - welcome to multiple years of career stalling
Perf process is opaque and in non-tech orgs, it's very manager dependent.
If you work there long enough, be prepared to find out that new people are being hired with less experience, greater compensation and better roles/titles/levels than you.
Internal mobility - opportunities abound but parity with market sucks!
Oh, and regardless of which team you are in, learn to play the political game or lose

headline: great place, just be aware it's 2021, it's a big company, usually the third mover
pros: The initial conditions of a company set a lot of vectors. Many of Google's initial conditions were good ones. The company still makes a big effort to be a nice place, not just because it's profitable, but because people (at least all the ones I see) genuinely want to get it right. They also want to at least try to make the world a better place, even if, arguably, that's not the corporation's big goal any more. Don't underestimate the value of this attitude, I've seen what it's like in so many companies that lack it. You see it in lots of things, big and small, that Google structurally makes an effort to make its employees life nice. Google got a lot right during covid, including being one of the first to provide free testing kits. I've got offers from a hot startup and AWS, and I'm pretty sure I am not ready to move.
cons:
Google is IBM. If you look at IBM in the 60s, they invented or reduced to practice so many fundamental ideas in computing (caching, virtualization, TLB) that we just take for granted now. They also made a bad guess and got bit numbering backwards, and decided to go with EBCDIC, and we still deal with that today, in code, docs, and programs. They can't back out of 50-year-old bad decisions. IBM has been around a long time, and it's harder and harder, post 1975, for them to innovate, as they are stuck in their cultural mold. Just look at the companies they keep buying. They break them every time.

Google is like that. They were the first to get to big scale in many areas, and you get stuck with that legacy base. It gets harder and harder to do something new. Microsoft has gitfs, Google has an older, not nearly as good srcfs. Everyone uses git, google is stuck with perforce. If you want to do anything really new, it's a giant effort, because there are so many stakeholders of "how we do it now." I've seen good ideas gnawed to death by ambitious, envious, ankle-biters. And, yes, performance review really does drive a lot of people to break things for no reason. Another chat app, anyone?

Google is like IBM ca 1990: still one of the leaders, but it's clearly not leading as it was, and there's blood in the water. Can the management fix it? That's not clear. The market is rewarding their current 'move slow and don't break things' model, so all the signals are green. As they were for, e.g., DEC or Sun or Intel, right before it all went wrong. Is Google the next Intel? Maybe.

headline: Prestigious, fascinating, great benefits but EXHAUSTING and poor work/life balance
pros: It's GOOGLE. Great benefits, probably the most stable OTE pay for a sales role EVER, perks galore, and the chance to develop yourself and shape your career path with the world's greatest resources.
cons: Despite the perks and the prestigious logo, work/life balance is poor. Google is filled to the brim with over-achievers always intent on promo or their next role. This, along with an INSATIABLE demand for growth, leads to unhealthy work/life balance. My teammates and I regularly burnout and get sick from exhaustion. Management knows about this and still lacks compassion. Instead of truly "seeing you," they say something like "working hard doesn't mean you are working smart." This sentiment hurts, especially when mgmt is constantly throwing you last-minute AIs and adding new OKRs/KPIs.

headline: Fantastic culture and mission
pros:
- The people is what makes this company great. Everyone is extremely intelligent, but very humble and kind. Google really does attract the best people (the genuinely good ones, school prestige doesn’t matter here).
- Strong mission to care about the users/customers, that they constantly emphasize
- Strong, genuine emphasis on diversity and psychological safety in the workplace because they really do understand the power of both. It’s unlike many companies who do it for image.
- Every org has strong leadership that drives and executes its strategy, so the business will definitely be sustained for a long time (no worries about unemployment or stagnation)
cons:
- Could be more transparent about compensation
- Frustrating lack of communication + unstable plans about return to office

headline: Still good, but has become a big company.
pros: Hiring & people philosophy. Hire very selectively to get very good people, then pay & treat them well to keep them.
cons:
Difficult to find a good role in the company.
- 75%+ (90%?) of projects are worthless/pointless & destined to go nowhere. On these projects, you can lead a team & the culture is typically good - but your work will never have a real impact.
- At most 25% of projects (probably less) have any chance of having much impact. On those projects, its very difficult to get a role as more than a cog. Also, those teams can afford to (and tend to) have a crappier culture & push people much harder because people want to work on them.
Most people end up working on things they aren't really interested in, or in roles they wouldn't take or stay-in at other companies.
Management quality varies *a lot*. I've seen some managers who were good at their job and also decent human beings. I've seen some that absolutely didn't deserve their roles, and/or that were vey sleazy. Google will basically always consider your manager to be correct in any dispute/disagreement with you, so a bad/sleazy manager can be very bad for your career at G.

headline: Google Cloud was fun but lacking in clear mission
pros: Pay, work-life balance, perks, had weekly 1-on-1s with manager
cons: Open office can be distracting, a lot of re-orgs while I was there, and the mission got a little lost in Cloud — at first it was about democratizing AI, but eventually we only talked bottom line

headline: Tons of great people but upward mobility is a challenge; very hierarchical with respect to Engineering levels
pros: Tons of interesting tech challenges; very bright people; great pay/benefits
cons: Upward mobility is a challenge; people on the Eng Manager ladder are overqualified and all competing for a small set of growth opportunities; you're not promoted until you've demonstrated sustained, next-level competence but you can't demonstrate next-level competence because they put you in a box based on your current level, preventing you from accessing such opportunities; your manager has to create a next-level opportunity for you to do so; so you're somewhat beholden to your manager to progress; very hierarchical with respect to Engineering levels; they mean more than you might imagine (especially if you've not worked for Big Tech companies before; down-leveling for experienced hires is the norm

headline: Amazing if not for a fatal flaw.
pros:
+) Extremely high compensation. When I switched to another big tech company, I actually ended up taking a small paycut despite getting a promotion.
+) Very flexible working hours (I had a coworker who worked four ten hour days and took Fridays off)
+) Excellent perks. Free food for three meals a day (of very good quality) plus snacks, and plenty of "teambuilding" events that are basically excuses to enjoy an afternoon off with coworkers.
+) A few years working at Google will make your resume and let you join pretty much any company you choose.
cons:
-) Extremely political. Google is all about bringing your whole self to work, so long as your whole self is progressive. There are a number of activists within the company who will protest at the drop of a hat. This may be a positive for some people, but anyone on the right, or even in the center of the political spectrum will have to bite their tongue to remain employed. 
-) Getting promoted within the company is a difficult ordeal, and the effort may not match the results.

headline: Good Company - Work Life Balance
pros:
Work Life Balance
Great Benefit All Around (health + retirement etc.)
cons:
Promo process is slow and many things outside of candidate's control (e.g. when a project you work on can produce meaningful impact for the company)
Lack of top-down culture (pro and con - many teams can sometimes step on each others toes and work on the same things and eventually there will be a re-org to sort it out (avg. every 2 yrs)). Unfortunately, for the engineers who worked on the deprecated products, it'll be hard for you to justify your 2 yrs worth of work for a promo if this happens.

headline: the best company
pros: Human resource is known as “People Operations” at Google to make it sound more friendly. This department uses data to take a proactive approach to ensure the happiness of employees. For instance, when Google noticed a higher turnaround rate for women, they looked at data and noticed most were new mothers, which led to the implenetation of a generous maternity leave policy.
cons: Many modern American companies have developed a contrived culture of lingering at work. Ambitious, new or young talent may end up hanging out at the office outside of work hours, often working or learning. This can develop into peer pressure to spend a lot of time at the office. Apart from coffee shops and libraries, some places have “sleep pods” for that swift power nap to help you keep going for longer. The Toronto Office even has a crazy golf putting green on the roof!

- company brand that still means a lot to many
cons:
Lots of great people are leaving and being replaced by people that are very junior, or with senior people with values that didn't use to be common at Google.

Senior management is often more interested in just creating an appearance of a happy and healthy company, rather than actually solving some hard problems.

A lot of technical debt that is increasingly hard to address due to the scale of the company.

In spite of increasingly making more and more money, the management invests less and less back into the company and its employees.

headline: Prepare to be pampered
pros:
1. Work with some of the very smartest people in the industry.
2. Perks on perks, endless perks, you won't even be able to find them all on the public internet, prepare to be pampered daily.
3. Some of the coolest tech offices in the world. And you can visit any of them at any time if you happen to be stopping by! (Not right now because of COVID, obviously)
4. Quite possibly the best internal tools in FAANG.
5. Stock is a rocketship right now.
6. Get first-hand insight on some really cool and cutting-edge projects. Although unfortunately, you won't always be allowed to talk about them externally.
7. On average, great WLB (30-40 hrs/wk). But as with any company, it's entirely team-dependent, so do your research before joining a team!
cons:
1. Pay is not as crazy as it was, say in 2010. (But still among the top in the industry)
2. Still some uncertainty around WFH policy.
3. Some of the projects are really cool but might never see the light of day. Just how big tech is though, sometimes.

headline: The grass is always greener
pros:
Excellent Compensation
Really Great Perks
Working with some of the best and brightest
Access to cutting edge technology
Prestige
cons:
Despite paying lip service to the importance of diversity, your success or failure at Google all comes down to who you boss is. The way that performance in sales roles is judged heavily favors neurotypical people in that you are expected to have immediate recall and be able to task switch constantly. 

This is incredibly difficult for people with ADHD and despite going to HR and opening conversations with my manager I was managed out, despite consistently hitting all of my sales goals.

There has also been a marked cultural shift away from the original core tenants. This comes with the type of growth they have experienced but it can be disheartening to see the values the company used to stand for be cast aside in the pursuit of ever increasing revenue goals.

headline: Google is an amazing place to work for the people, the growth, scale, variety and perks!
pros:
-) The people (coworkers are smart & nice). 
-) The growth (you willl get invaluable development feedback from 360 degree reviews, that, if you are able to internalize and incorporate the feedback, will propel your career forward)
-) Variety. So many groups in one place, that when you're ready for your next career exploration, it will be easy and smooth. Google wants to be the last place you'll ever work.
-) Scale. If you want to have lots of users, in some cases billions, Google is a lot of fun and you are helping many people who use your product directly or indirectly. 
-) Free food and stocked "micro-kitchens" with snacks. And, the shuttles (okay, in 2020-21 this isn't a factor, but it will be when we all go back.)
Help the environment and make friends with neighbors, while riding a climate controlled bus with leather seats and friendly bus drivers, to work & back. If you can read in cars, you also will probably be able to get all your email done on the way to and from work, and the day is just about getting real work done.
cons: It is a large company, with over 100,000 employees, so there are often many people involved in any given project. You will need to be patient to work with stakeholders. Most teams have minimal politics so this goes smoothly. Things take longer than in a startup, but on the other hand, the scale of users, products, infrastructure is much greater.

headline: Google Shopping/Express - Difficult experience at best
pros: Lots of perks, such as food, shuttle, personal and professional development classes. Good, smart, hard-working peers.
cons:
Google Shopping (formerly Express) was quite the hot mess, essentially an immature, messy start-up despite being a part of the larger Alphabet family. No clear vision or direction, more like 'let's throw stuff on the wall and see what sticks.'

Very frustrating experience to be a part of -- unrealistic work loads on the shoulders of a few, constant clashing between different groups that were supposed to be collaborative and working towards the same goal (i.e. the customer). Very hard to make data-driven decisions for the customer with constant bullying and micro-aggressions from the Category Management team to push their specific agenda (i.e. revenue goals and merchant favoritism).

A constant revolving door of contractors who did the majority of the work, who were under constant pressure, overworked, and under-appreciated and under-valued. Direct management of such contractors couldn't even be bothered to manage, engage, or acknowledge these extended workforce folks.

headline: Best perks / tech of any company I've worked for, but decisions are now slow
pros: Can't beat the perks (international travel opportunities, education stipend, etc.) and the technical innovation you are surrounded by pretty much anywhere else; total comp pay is high but not as high as that of Facebook (still very solid though) and the things you can work on are more varied (Google is in so many industries).
cons: It can take a really long time for senior leaders to make a decision because it's such a big company and you are rewarded for steering the ship slowly and safely, not for risk-taking. Like any big company, it also has its own team and internal politics that result in building what someone wants (maybe for their own personal passion or career advancement) and not for what the customer might want or what's best for Google.

pros: Can't beat the perks (international travel opportunities, education stipend, etc.) and the technical innovation you are surrounded by pretty much anywhere else; total comp pay is high but not as high as that of Facebook (still very solid though) and the things you can work on are more varied (Google is in so many industries).
cons: It can take a really long time for senior leaders to make a decision because it's such a big company and you are rewarded for steering the ship slowly and safely, not for risk-taking. Like any big company, it also has its own team and internal politics that result in building what someone wants (maybe for their own personal passion or career advancement) and not for what the customer might want or what's best for Google.

headline: Foot In Door To Google
pros: You get to work with intelligent (socially and book smart) people constantly whether they are your customers or your coworkers. You don’t have to know Google Ads to start the role and they train you in the product very well. By a year in the role you’ll be in the 95% percentile of Google ads experts and you’ll have the opportunity to explore other roles at Google if you please. If you do well your pay goes through yearly refreshes and It can make a huge difference. You get to bring your whole self to work and that’s really cool.
cons: If you are joining the role from another company It is very vague if you will come into the role as an L2 (hourly) or L3 and that can make a big difference in compensation. People with 2-3 years of experience can make the same as a college grad and that can be frustrating. While pay has the potential to go up if you perform well, promotions can feel slow due to only 2 cycles a year which can limit you from going to roles that require certain levels. You will be challenged and need to have discipline, but it’s not a cutthroat environment in the slightest everyone helps everyone.

headline: Loads of Commitment for Slightly Above-Average Pay
pros:
Above-Average Pay
Good People for the most part
High-quality Ad Products to sell (relative to competitors)
Solid 401k match and benefits
Global work community
Indirectly supports Alphabet's attempts to solve existential human challenges
cons:
Below average vacation days (inconsistent depending on country)
Wolf-in-sheep's clothing managerial styles / psychological tactics
Undeniable workaholic-culture, despite internal rhetoric to the contrary
"if it ain't completely broke, don't fix it" mentality with internal/external products
Under-staffed (at least in sales), resulting in excessively high client ratios
Under-resourced, creating productivity and scoping dilemmas
Advancement can be impossible if you are on the wrong team, at the wrong level, with the wrong manager

headline: Great Launchpad to Senior Strategy Roles
pros: Gain experience generating millions of dollars and managing tens of millions more. Alumni from other parts of Alphabet come speak all the time, so internal transfers are pretty transparent. It's Google, so benefits are top of the top. Free gourmet food that changes every day (with some popular staples),  free dessert, free barista-made coffee, free snacks. And that's just the food, not to mention free gym, free rock climbing walls, free Ayco (Goldman Sachs) financial advice, free massages, etc. Plus, the people are super quirky, getting to know any one of them is so fascinating. There's always something that sticks out, like "oh! that's their special quirk". I remember my first day meeting people that came to Google from producing Emmy award-winning shows, are related to people that founded a literal sport, or have been to all continents. Google is full of incredibly smart people with interesting stories to tell.
cons: There are a crazy amount of benefits that its hard to keep track of. The main ones are listed and obvious but some more niche ones, or office-specific perks (like the free Lime scooters for some locations) are harder to find unless you spot the email. Maybe its more of a west coast office thing, but  people are very easy going. I kind of wish it were a bit more competitive and people would flex more. I'm proud of the work people are doing but they gotta speak up!

headline: Interesting experience, but not what I expected or hoped for.
pros:
People.
General culture.

Couldn't tell you about the perks, because I joined during the pandemic, so there are no perks.
cons:
Pay isn't quite what it should be, though they claim it's "market rate". It's not.. Well below, but they figure they'll get someone since the app rate is so high.

If you join them, make sure you join actual Google, not wind up in some company they acquired that is going to take years to acclimate. You'll never get to experience actual Google life. I joined Google for the Google experience, and instead got the GoogleNotGoogle experience.

cons: Performance review cycles and promotion can be cumbersome, and the general size of the company means bureaucracy and communication between departments is difficult. Internal divide between the treatment of contract workers and full-time workers causes friction, and the companies mission and direction are becoming increasingly corporate.

headline: Bad Promo Process and Mediocre Salary
pros: Google has an awesome company culture and perks. Culture: management is accessible, your voice can be heard at team meetings and even all-hands meetings, people respect you, and I always felt cared about as a person. Perks: I thoroughly enjoyed the free breakfast/lunch/dinner, baristas, gym, commuter bus, and subsidized massages.
cons:
Google has to make some serious changes to improve its performance management and promotion processes. Called "Perf", it's a twice a year process that managers and staff alike despise because it takes up enormous amounts of time and results in questionable promotion decisions. 

In Finance, approximately 10% of the team can get promoted in any given Perf cycle and there are only two per year. I recommend learning about Google's internal level system during the hiring process and asking what level your role is before you accept the job offer. Talk to a friend or contact and see if the leveling of your role is reasonable to start with. I was hired at too low of a level and then slow (3 years) to reach my first promotion. 

Finance Levels at Google (rough work experience required):

L3 Financial Analyst (1-2 years)
L4 Financial Analyst (2-4 years)
L5 Senior Financial Analyst (4-6 years)
L6 Finance Manager (6-8 years)
L7 & L7.5 Senior Finance Manager (8+)
L8 Finance Director (12+)

L5 is the terminal level for many Finance employees. It's extremely difficult to get into management. L6 and above are very political promotions. For promotions at levels 3-5, they are largely time-based (2 years on average for L3/L4, 3 years for L5). Super strong performers do not get promoted more quickly, contrary to what Google claims. 

While total compensation (salary + 15% bonus + equity) is often competitive, the salary component is quite low and makes it hard to afford the SF Bay Area cost of living, especially in your first year before you get a bonus and before any of your equity vests.

headline: Amazing brand name but Recruiters are ALL facing burnout
pros:
Amazing Brand
Great benefits and perks
Competitive Salary for Recruiters
Great offices and amenities (when they're open)
cons:
Work from Home decisions have been very fickle
Microcosm of culture depending on what Product Area you're in
Recruiters are all burned out - so many requisitions - so little support from leaders
Not a representative workforce and especially not in Staffing/Recruiting - very few black and latinx recruiters - and almost no leaders from these backgrounds which is puzzling given our commitments to DEI
Psychologically Safety really varies by team - it's hard to be vocal bc you're always nervous of consequences and don't want to rock the boat

headline: One year at Google review
pros:
Incredible on-site benefits

Heavy investment into diversity equity and inclusion.

Great work life balance and ability to shut work off to focus on your family. Great support across the organization for this.
cons:
Each of the leaders operates in their own silo, this causes confusion, duplicate work, and no vision cross-organizationally.

There is a ton of red tape to get through to make even the smallest of change for the better.

The organization has a very anti sales culture.

There are some serious issues with the wage gap still at this organization between male and female workers.

headline: It's Google
pros: Huge scale problems, lot's of interesting technical stuff to work on. Very chill culture, bordering on too chill. Great people to work with (in my experience from the Madison office).
cons: Lot's of bureaucracy, slow pace for development/promotion. Products are often over engineered, creating large teams when smaller teams with better direction would be just as well.

headline: Great people and benefits, too much bureaucracy
pros:
- Colleagues are as a rule friendly, helpful, intelligent.
- Easy transfers between projects and orgs, many different and interesting problems to work on.
- Great office benefits, global presence makes travel + work easy. Good pay.
- Great work-life balance if you want it, little danger in getting managed out. Good (but slow) advancement opportunities as IC or EM if you want to work hard.
cons:
- So much process and bureaucracy. Most of it is well-intentioned but project planning and launch is very CYA
- Slow-moving by default. Everyone is capable of being very productive, but moving fast doesn't seem rewarded much more than moving slow.
- Giant company, no individual project gets much exec attention or moves the needle much on P&L

headline: Overall good work environment, highly team dependent though
pros:
Google is well known for its perks. In non-covid times the offices are well equipped, all the snacks, food, gyms, massage rooms, nap pods. It's the stuff of much satire. It's very nice.

The compensation is really good. Collaboration across teams can be great, although it does depend on product area. The culture in the company and much of the scandal that comes out is born out of transparency and freedom. Freedom to express yourself many employers stomp down on and sometimes.... it's too much but usually it's quite freeing.
cons:
The promotion process at google is well intentioned but poor, IMO. It is honestly probably the single biggest reason google is known for abandoning products. We develop things for promotions because that's what gets them. Maintaining and improving or spending the energy to rebuild and transfer data doesnt get you a promotion.

You need to land something, but you also need to excel for over a year this dissuades people pushing to do something to try and get a promotion which is good but also disincentivizing. The whole thing is political, you need to land grab at times to get work other teams might be doing so they can't do it.... again so you can get promoted. If you land in the right place at the right time it is easy to move up, rising tides raise all ships. A bad manager, a bad product idea, can sink you even if you are doing good work.

- Great learning opportunities as you can virtually sign up to learn anything internally as Google has many different teams/orgs/functions.
cons: Given the size of the company, it might be tough to tie your work to the impact you are making. If "what" you do matters and if you are not passionate about advertising, it can be tough to grow further. Additionally, each team/org has their drawback, whether it is an excessive focus on metrics/target, or how you need to manage upward to get further in the corporate ladder (but one can argue that you need that skill anywhere in life).

headline: Top Tier Company
pros: My favorite thing about working at Google is the people you work alongside. Everyone I have ever worked with at Google is an intelligent, hard working, and overall kind person. The work environment is also fast paced, ambiguous, innovative and rewarding. The company has a great culture overall and a lot of opportunity for learning and growth.
cons: It can be difficult to land a role in your location of preference due to high competition and focus on specific hub offices. In addition, job mobility can be harder when you are in business and non-Eng roles. Most positions are also located in expensive cities which may not work as well for people further in their career with greater preference and limitation on where they are willing to live.

headline: A shell of it's former self
pros: Benefits are solid. Health, dental, yearly bonus, vacation, and pay raises are amazing.
cons:
The culture and environment has become a joke. Google was once the most sought after company for employment, but it has lost it's unique charm from over a decade ago. Now it's a corporate monster that has grown far too big. We were once the #1 company on Forbes' 100 best companies to work for and it hurt us deeply when we dropped to #2 after many years at the top. Fast forward to 2020 and we don't even make the top 100.

There is a serious lack of coherence and communication anymore. Motivation to succeed is not based on making great products, but instead on what you can do for promotion. This is clearly evident in the products we develop - or develop then abandon. It's also why we once had nine discrete messaging apps while many other products included messaging functions.

The world would be a better place if great ideas like Google Fiber, Stadia, and Voice were better executed. However, we're left with products that are not only made fun of by the public, but given countdown clocks to when they'll be discontinued. What remains are disjointed products like Gmail - including a UI so butchered and bloated, they needed to add a loading screen so you didn't think long loads times means the service is down. 

We once did great work and were on the top of the tech world. This is no longer the case and I doubt we could ever get there again. We're too large, too slow, too disparate, and have so many competing visions, that there is no return to our former glory days.

headline: Rushed out the Door
pros: Free food, nice offices, resources for mental health that you'll probably need after working there for a while.
cons:
In my experience the focus has been on rushing something out the door. Not necessarily something good, or something completely functional (even for the minimal features in the MVP), just something. Frequently software is rushed, testing is skimped on, and higher up engineers are unwilling to learn modern software development practices to improve software performance, reliability, developer experience, and user experience.

If you do not like to cut corners, do not work at Google. After spending 4 years here, being told by 3 managers that I care too much about my work and spend too much time making it right (while simultaneously being dinged on perf for it being 'not right enough'), and witnessing Google's willingness to protect sexual abusers and the bottom line over its purported values, the veneer of friendliness seems very disingenuous.

headline: Incredible growth
pros: Google cloud is growing rapidly, and that opens up growth opportunities constantly. There's an unbelievable innovation pace, new products/features being released all the time. The people at Google is really the best, there's a lot of great talent, and while Google needs to continue to improve the diversity, specially on management roles, I think the Google Cloud team is fairly diverse.
cons: There's a lot of change, and for some people this could be stressful, because there's a lot of adjustment needed. There are changes at all levels including compensation/salary changes. Another con is that in it's effort to catch up with the cloud market leaders, Google is becoming a traditional enterprise software company, and is loosing some of its values, culture, and identity.

headline: Long Term Lookback
pros: Excellent meals. Generally a great work environment. Superb internal tools. Folks are nice. Very low pressure environment.
cons:
Lots of talent there, but not always clear what to work on. Warehouses full of shelf-ware. Many half baked projects start and are vaporized when they lead nowhere. This is a good strategy for Google - as a monopoly they the can start a 1000 projects - if a couple turn out well they write the others off - as their giant cash machine covers all costs.

One beef; it's harder being older there. Explicit age-ism was very rare, but there was a strong strain of "let's celebrate youth" - the famous "take your parents to work day". Once in a while I was on the receiving side of some condescending nonsense as an "unwoke" ancient. It's precious snowflake central - nice kids - but they've no clue on how the rest of the working world works.

headline: Good gig, tough advancement for women
pros: The benefits are excellent and colleagues are smart and kind. Competitive pay. Good parental leave. Access to a lot of training resources.
cons: It is hard to advance as a woman, especially if you are not an engineer or a product manager. HR does not deal with investigations in a transparent way. It’s a boy’s club and can be emotionally exhausting. It’s very hard to get promoted, but it’s not a bad place to spend a few years. Unfair things happen all the time. If you can emotionally disengage, you can have a good personal life.

headline: Not bad
pros:
There are a ton of opportunities to do anything. Good place to rest and vest if you’d like. They do a great job of offering things to make
Your job easier.
cons: Very corporate and tons of red tape. It’s super easy to get lost and feel frustrated by constant change. Very entitled coworkers are very annoying.

headline: Great place to grow and learn steadily in your middle to late career
pros: Benefits and perks are industry-leading, and work culture is very conducive to separating work and life. I feel supported by the policies and management expectations that are put in place to encourage wellness, honest feedback, and time off when necessary. The average tenure of a Googler seems longer than the average big-tech (ex-FB), and I think that's due to the long-term mobility you can find here - whether it's across business units, movement to XFN teams, and even to new markets/offices.
cons: Very large and ever-growing company creates a lot of product and workstream silos, potential for overlap, and definitely an incredibly heavy consensus-driven culture. Working here teaches you to collaborate and manage internal stakeholders, but this comes at the expense (sometimes) of moving quickly and feeling autonomous.

headline: Finding Impact in Your Niche
pros:
- Very competitive compensation, regular comp refresh 
- Smart coworkers, relatively horizontal structure (in sales) allows for collaboration
- No micromanagement, very flexible and balanced schedule 
- Opportunity to drive impact at scale, albeit in a very narrow part of the business 
- Ability to pursue new interests through 20% projects in other parts of the company 
- The best physical office environment you can imagine (personal trainers, peloton, lunch, etc.); some nice WFH covid perks to compensate in this time
cons:
- Massive company, lots of red tape to cut through when building anything new 
- Lost focus on the end-user in advertising sales, all about revenue numbers 
- Laborious promotion process, but yearly salary refresh helps with this 
- Very difficult to move between job ladders (ex. program mgmt vs. sales) despite outward appearance of career mobility; requires tenacity and patience to move around the company 
- "Googleyness" somewhat, but a more conventional company these days

headline: If the guy who threatened my job could get promoted, this is not the place where I want to work.
pros:
The pay was decent for the bay.
Lots of amazing people, got to meet and see all kinds of cool people. 
Got to travel
Occasional perks made some things nicer, but they were often ephemeral. 
FTE status for extra perks sometimes.
cons:
Too much to complain about. I deleted a lot that would have probably identified me. 

My first manager threatened my job in a private meeting. Told me other managers were gossiping about me. He told me my job was in danger if I kept submitting negative feedback about his (eventually proven to be bad) idea. I communicated that the expectations set when I started were being abandoned. I told him how my last job they hired me away from stuck to their expectations at least, and he told me to go back to my old job. 

Another manager, in a small meeting of himself and some ITRs did it to a group of people once too. "Remember, we're the ones who sign your conversion papers". I didn't feel secure and was often anxious around management, because I never knew who was gossiping about me and who wasn't. 

How would you react to this kind of hostility? I was too afraid to report him, so I watched him get promoted away from his mistakes and failed responsibilities. I was mentorless, directionless, and the guy who I thought was looking out for me was just looking out for himself. 

This kind of trash happened more than once, and the managers should be ashamed of themselves for starting cliques and discouraging honest, candid feedback. 

This program was not googly, and this is not the only reason.

cons: The job is a little boring. A lot of what made it famous early on -- 20% time, for instance, and real transparency from leadership, to name two such things -- have withered away as the company has grown to its current global status. It's a big company with a lot of bureaucracy. There's a lot of red tape and approvals to go through nowadays. No one at Google today is creating the next Gmail in their free time.

headline: All in all, an outstanding place to work.
pros:
* The employee's fight to keep the company as "good" as possible.
* The business model allows for the company to provide outstanding free services (gmail, calendar, maps, etc)
* It is on you to prove yourself for promotion (also a con) which means that managers don't unilaterally decide who should get promoted based on biases and favoritism.
cons:
* The employees have grown to expect to continue to be treated extremely well (pay, benefits, and perks).
* It is on you to prove yourself for promotion (also a pro) which leads to a "do what makes you look good, not do what is good" perspective.
* Because most people make a lot of money, there is a wealth culture that exists and that at least bothers me.

headline: Place to experience teacher burn out, high turnover, and
pros:
You get a lot of the corporate perks of the company.
Unlimited sick leave
Cafes and gyms
Helps apply to other positions at google. 
You get to be a googler
cons:
You’re not really a googler
US interns get paid more than you.
Forced spring break to eat up 1 week of allotted vacation hours.
Morale is low.
High turnover
Caps out at teacher 3.
Google directors are level 8
You need to request pto a year or more in advance.
Work life balance is struggle with requesting pto/flexibility with management.

headline: Great company where personal growth can stagnate
pros:
Amazing people
Great perks
Lots of fun problems to work on
3/5 bosses were excellent, 1/5 bosses was good (and the other would show up in the cons)
RSU stock grants were amazing. If you stay at Google for a few years, those RSUs really start to stack.
cons:
Sales job (initial entry level job) became boring pretty quick - lots of sales reps tried to move into product / strategy roles (with good reasons I think)
Google is now just a big company - there's lots of people and a competitive talent pool. This makes getting stretch opportunities a rarity.
Lots of distraction from day-to-day work with protests against Google in China, DoD deals, sexual harassment, etc. While the sexual harassment protests were definitely merited and Andy Rubin was absolutely in the wrong, I thought there was frequently more negativity than was warranted against the company that fed you 3x/day, paid you handsomely, and gave you the chance to interact with other amazing people.

headline: An amazing and dynamic place to work
pros: Given the resources and autonomy to work on problems that matter and energize. I am given scope and guidance to really excel in this amazing environment with incredibly smart and kind co-workers. The office is energizing and so much fun, I truly love going to work every day and consider myself incredibly well looked after.
cons: Working from home during 2020 has been tough but I think we have been cared for as well as possible through this period. As the company grows it does lose its high-energy and weird feeling to some extent although there are concerted efforts to minimize the erosion of company culture.

headline: Google's custom stack is both its greatest asset and its greatest liability
pros:
- Fantastic benefits
- It's Google
- Lots of opportunities to learn new skills
cons:
Keep in mind that my experience is limited to a single group within Google.
- Work happens in isolation
- No team culture
- Work is 45% research, 45% documentation, 10% coding (being generous)
- I had 4 bosses in less than 2 years
- Diversity and inclusion is cool and necessary but takes too much room
- Move up or move out culture

headline: As tech jobs go It's pretty good but I'm not sure I personally like it here
pros:
- smart, kind, helpful coworkers who want to see you succeed! 
- lots and lots of possible stuff to work on internally, bc google really does Everything
- the perks + good job stability
- good work life balance; my workload is totally manageable
- cool to work on stuff that so many people use
cons:
- the company (and codebase) is so big it will swallow you whole if you are not careful
- getting promoted / "growing" in your career is a big corporate game which feels slimy at times, to me 
- takes forever to launch anything. sometimes you will work for months and months at a time on something and the project will get cancelled. it's fine when this happens once but when it happens several times in a row it can be disheartening
- the culture of your specific team & manager kind of defines your experience
- can feel like a cog in the machine

headline: Smart coworkers and great perks, but may have to fight for good projects
pros: You get to work with some of the smartest people around. You get to use awesome developer tools-- everybody who leaves misses the tools. Great perks: free food, gym onsite, etc. Very stable and secure job (even during covid). It will look good on your resume forever if you can get here! I'd say try to get in and work a few years to build your skillset but if you don't get a good project then move on.
cons: So many smart and ambitious people who want to do the Next Great Thing that it can be hard to get a chance to work on a good project. Some people can get lost in the shuffle. It is a Big Company. The interview to get in is a bit of a lottery-- lots of super smart people don't get in on the first try... or second try.

headline: Awesome benefits, very entitled colleagues, not always the greatest culture
pros: Google treats it's people well. While you're working at google, you can trust that your benefits are nearly as good as they get, and your salary is probably about 80% as good as it gets.
cons: People who are fresh out of college, or maybe have been at Google too long, forget what other jobs in the field are like. The reference for comparison can be very skewed. At the same time, management can talk a big game about the culture that google has, but rarely lives up to the promises of transparency, and innovative thinking, etc. But it's such a big company, I'm sure this is all department by department, team by team.

headline: Straightforward remote internship

This is largely related to the remote working experience as us summer 2020 interns were entirely remote. It worked very well and there is a clear focus on maintaining a high-level of communication, likely supported by Google's cross-campus nature. Google has managed remote work very well.

People are receptive to communication outside the team, even if it takes a ping to get them sometimes. That's a big deal
cons: No free food or coffee when remote working.

headline: Good benefits, bad everything else
pros:
Google pays reasonably well, and makes an effort to keep employees happy enough to stay.
The benefits are great, and the pay is competitive.
cons:
It is nearly impossible to transfer into engineering if you aren’t already there, and the company culture is very strange. You are expected to be friends with your coworkers, and you are expected to treat Google as though it is the best company in the world. 
The diversity and inclusion strategies are very tokenizing. As a queer person, I was immediately asked to get involved with diversity efforts. 
The culture also seems to be such that people like to pretend that Google is not a corporation that makes money.
Worth mentioning also that I was hired for a job description that had nothing to do with my actual role. 
They told me it was consulting but turns out it was product support. Big fat lie.
Also, the team I was on did things that were antithetical to the company’s “mission” and cloaked it under the guise of a necessary evil. 

Basically, unless they offer you a job as an engineer, avoid.

headline: Scale is a Pro and a Con
pros: Scale up your impact by working for a company with billions of users, a culture that is focused on the right things, and brilliant coworkers.
cons: Changing a system with billions of users is harder than changing smaller systems. Google today is cautious, deliberative, and process heavy. Much of what makes an engineer successful at Google today is their ability to navigate the hierarchy, build consensus, and document everything. If you want to crank out code, iterate quickly, or focus on technical tasks Google is not the place for you.
